content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

From the thumbnail, I see a section of fibro-adipose tissue containing a large, well-circumscribed, basophilic (purple) nodule. This nodule is highly cellular and appears to be an almost completely replaced lymph node. There is also some black pigment (anthracosis) present. The overall first impression is of a large, positive (metastatic) lymph node.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because the large, basophilic nodule is the most prominent feature on the slide and is morphologically consistent with a lymph node. At low power, it appears almost entirely replaced by a different cell population, lacking the typical architecture of a reactive lymph node (e.g., distinct cortex, medulla, and germinal centers). This is highly suspicious for metastatic disease, and zooming in is necessary to examine the cellular morphology to confirm the presence of carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see two distinct populations of cells separated by a fibrous band. On the right, there are sheets and poorly-formed glands of malignant epithelial cells. These cells are large with pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. On the left, there is a dense infiltrate of small, dark, round cells, which are residual lymphocytes from the original lymph node. My impression is that this confirms the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma within a lymph node, making this a positive lymph node.
